front.reference: Chemistry of Heterocyclic Compounds, VoL 34, No. 3, 1998

docTitle.titlePart:
REACTION OF DERIVATIVES OF 1,4-DIHYDROPYRIDINE
WITH THE PEROXYNITRITE ANION

byline.docAuthor: G. Tirzitis, E. Kazush, and G. Duburs

front.div:
The peroxynitrite anion (ONOO-) is a strong oxidant and is formed from nitrogen superoxide and oxide both in model
systems and in the body [1, 2]. On protonation, the peroxynitrite anion forms unstable peroxynilrous acid (ONOOH) which
spontaneously decomposes with the formation of hydroxyl radical (HO) and (NO2") [3]. The physiological role of the
peroxynitrite anion is not yet clear, but it is a strong bactericidal compound whose intense formation damages surrounding
tissues in the region of phagoeytosis. The role of the peroxynitrite anion as a participant in the secondary alarm system in the
cell is discussed in [4].
1,4-DHP has radioprotective, antiaggregation, and other types of physiological activity in addition to the well-known
cardiovascular action [5, 6]. Derivatives of 1,4-DHP not substituted in position 4 are antioxidants [7] and have high reactivity
with respect to free radicals [8].
The reaction of some water-soluble derivatives of 1,4-DHP (I), including derivatives of 1,4-dihydroisonicotinic acid,
with the peroxynitrite anion and the products of this reaction and the effect of derivatives I on the lifetime of the peroxynitrite
anion and formation of hydroxyl radical from the anion were investigated to study the reactivity of physiologically active
derivatives of 1,4-DHP with biological oxidants.
